standard_metadata.standard_description: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.

hints.content: To make a $15^\circ$ angle, we move the [[☃ definition 1]] to the middle dot of the protractor.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A protractor shows points plotted at 160 and 180 degrees. Rays are drawn out from the vertex in the protractor's center through each point.

hints.content: Next, we line up one of the rays on the $0^\circ$ line of the protractor.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A protractor shows points plotted at 0 and 180 degrees. Rays are drawn out from the vertex in the protractor's center through each point.

hints.content: Finally, we move the other ray around until it is lined up with the $15^\circ$ measurement on the protractor.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A protractor shows points plotted at 0 and 15 degrees. Rays are drawn out from the vertex in the protractor's center through each point.

hints.content: The following angle measures $15^\circ$.   *The rays may point in a different direction, but the amount of rotation between them must be the same.*  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An angle is formed by two rays extending out from a common point. The size of the angle is the same as in the previous image.
